greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: A(n,k) is the n-th number m such that a nontrivial prime(k)-th root of unity modulo m exists; square array A(n,k), n>=1, k>=1, read by antidiagonals.
comment: The trivial square roots of unity modulo m are {1, m-1} and for an odd prime p the trivial p-th root of unity modulo m is 1.
There is no prime in the first column.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Antidiagonals n = 1..200, flattened
maple: A:= proc() local j, l; l:= proc() [] end;
if k=1 and phi(j)> lambda(j) or k>1 and
mathematica: A[n_, k_] := Module[{j, l = {}}, While[Length[l]<n, For[j = 1+If[l == {}, 0, l[[-1]]], True, j++, If[k==1 && EulerPhi[j]>CarmichaelLambda[j] || k>1 && Mod[EulerPhi[j], Prime[k]]==0, AppendTo[l, j]; Break[]]]]; l[[n]]];
Table[A[n, 1 + d - n], {d, 1, 15}, {n, 1, d}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, May 29 2018, from Maple *)
xref: Row n=1 gives A066674 for k>1.
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Nov 03 2016
